awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Advancement of Computational Modeling to Understand Mechanisms of Neonatal Brachial Plexus Injury
awd_abstract_narration:
Neonatal brachial plexus palsy (NBPP) occurs at a rate of 1/1000 births, with 10-20% of children who sustain the injury experiencing a permanent paralysis of some or all of the muscles in one of their arms.  It occurs when the nerves that supply the arm – the brachial plexus – is injured.  It is widely accepted that the vast majority of NBPP are biomechanical in nature and occur during the birth process.  An improved understanding of the mechanisms through which the brachial plexus is stretched during the birth process is necessary in order to better inform clinical interventions and decision making that may reduce the occurrence or severity of the injury.  Computational modeling provides the best approach to understand the mechanism of injury in a vulnerable population, such as newborns.  This project will develop an advanced computational model to represent natural biological variability and the full process of delivery in order to investigate the mechanism of NBPP.  The paralysis that results from NBPP can result in a lifelong disability, as it affects motor innervation of the entire upper extremity.  Before new recommendations for clinical interventions and decision making can be developed, it is imperative that the mechanism of injury is more completely understood.  Once developed and validated, this model will serve as a foundation for future computational work to investigate the mechanisms of other biomechanical injuries that occur during the birth process – including potentially vascular injuries (e.g. cerebral hemorrhages) and bony fractures.  In addition to the scientific impact, the research team will work with established outreach programs at Michigan State to explain the importance of biomechanics in understanding how injuries occur and to excite the public about the field of biomechanics.  Modules developed for outreach will be made available in virtual formats, which will broaden the reach of these materials.


Two scientific objectives have been established to support the goal of this project: 1) to develop an advanced model that combines finite element and rigid body modeling methods to mimic the appropriate boundary conditions and delivery forces involved with the occurrence of NBPP; and 2) to utilize the model to parametrically investigate the factors that affect the stretch that occurs in the brachial plexus during the birth process, which subsequently increases the risk of injury.   The model will integrate and advance techniques related to modeling of biological soft tissues, including non-linear soft tissue structures of complex geometries and active muscle tissue.  It will significantly advance the science of NBPP biomechanics by including advanced modeling for both maternal and neonatal tissues, a novel approach within the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Neonatal brachial plexus palsy (NBPP) is an injury that occurs in approximately 1/1000 births, with 10 to 20 percent of those resulting in a persistent deficit in movement and/or sensation in the arm.  As injury biomechanics cannot be studied in a living baby, and access to neonatal cadavers is complicated by the sensitivity of the situation when a still birth or early neonatal death occurs, the only way to better understand the mechanisms of NBPP is through surrogates.  Animal surrogates have proven to be particularly useful in understanding the properties of the infant brachial plexus – but they cannot be used to study the effect of the birth process on the infant.  Physical and computational models can better mimic the birth process – and each has their limitations.  This project opted to advance computational models in order to ultimately understand more about the factors that impact the stretch of the brachial plexus – and this an increased risk of injury – related to the mother, the newborn, and the physiology of labor and delivery.  This project resulted in the development of several novel computational models, all of which can be used to better understand the mechanisms of NBPP. 

First, a finite element model of the female pelvis was developed – including pelvic soft tissues – and a mathematical description of the “curve of Carus” was created and validated.  The “curve of Carus” is the path that the infant follows through the pelvis – curved because the infant’s body interacts with the bony pelvis, which is an irregular structure.  This finite element model was validated against clinical findings and other models of pelvic tissue deformation during delivery.  Just as primary experiments to understand mechanisms of NBPP cannot be conducted on an infant during birth, the collection of precise tissue response data from a laboring patient for the validation of models of labor and delivery is not feasible.   This model demonstrated that the use of a mathematical definition for the curve of Carus provided a reproducible model – and one that could be more easily compared between research groups.

Second, the goal was established to create – for the first time – a model of uterine contraction that could deliver a model infant through the pelvis without applying a force or displacement directly to the neonate.  This was accomplished by: 1) creating units (or fibers) of smooth muscle for which the contraction properties could be defined; 2) integrating those units into a uterine model that had the fibers arranged to mimic the anatomical arrangement and that could contract in the time varying way that is observed clinically; and 3) combining the uterine model with the pelvic model to demonstrate how uterine contractions alone could be deliver the baby’s head.  Previous models of childbirth generally relied on either a force being applied to the center of mass of the infant or dictating a path along which the infant would travel through the pelvis, without any consideration of force. 

Finally, the first 3D finite element model of the neonatal brachial plexus – and the first 3D model of the brachial plexus from any age group that included anatomically defined structures beyond the level of the divisions – was developed and validated.  The first step in the modeling of the plexus – which involved developing a 2D model of the brachial plexus with anatomically appropriate segment anatomy for the roots and trunks – demonstrated that even small changes in anatomy (e.g., a change in the angle between the nerve root and the spinal cord) could result in a significant change in the resulting stress at the level of the nerve root – and thus a significant change in the risk of injury.  The follow-on 3D finite element model – which included anatomically appropriate dimensions from the nerve roots through to the start of the distal nerve structures – demonstrated how the stress occurs first at the level of the C5 nerve root.  This is a key finding from the clinical realm.  It also, for the first time, confirmed biomechanically the process of how the injury progresses down from C5 through the lower nerve roots without the need to add more force to the distal end of the nerve roots. 

The next step will be to combine these models in order to allow more refined variations in labor and delivery physiology or individual variations in anatomy and tissue properties to be investigated as they relate to increased risk of neonatal brachial plexus injury.


Last Modified: 03/10/2025
Modified by: Michele J Grimm
